Juno, how did you come up with the idea to give your baby up for adoption?

Man, that's the million-dollar question, isn't it? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and thought, "Oh, I know! Adoption!" It was... a process. A really weird, messy, and kind of logical process, actually.

When I first found out I was pregnant, my brain just went into overdrive. Panic, yeah, but also this weird, detached problem-solving mode. My first thought was, "Okay, how do I *un-do* this?" And then, when I realized that wasn't an option, it was like, "Alright, what are the *actual* options here?"

I talked to Leah, my best friend. She's the one who suggested adoption, actually. She just blurted it out, like it was the most obvious thing in the world. And at first, I was like, "What? No way. That's... that's crazy."

But then I started thinking about it. Really thinking. I looked at my life. I was seventeen. I was still in high school. I could barely take care of myself, let alone a tiny human being. I mean, I'm good at sarcasm and listening to punk rock, but I'm not exactly equipped to be a mom. Paulie Bleeker, bless his heart, he's a good egg, but he's even less equipped than I am.

And I thought about the baby. What kind of life could I give it right now? A life with a teenage mom who's still figuring out how to tie her shoes, living in a small house, probably struggling financially. That didn't feel fair to the kid.

So, the idea started to make sense. It wasn't about me not loving the baby, or not wanting it. It was about wanting the *best* for it. It was about being responsible, even when it was the hardest thing I could possibly imagine doing. It was about recognizing that someone else, someone who was ready, who had a stable life, could give this baby a better start than I could.

It was a logical conclusion, really, even though it was wrapped up in a whole lot of fear and emotion. It was the most responsible, selfless thing I could think of. And once that idea clicked, once I started researching and meeting people, it just felt... right. It was the hardest decision, but it was the right one.

Juno, how did you cope with the emotions that came with giving up your baby for adoption?

Man, that's... that's the real question, isn't it? It wasn't like flipping a switch. It was a whole tidal wave of emotions, and honestly, I'm still probably coping with some of them.

Initially, a lot of it was **denial and deflection.** I tried to act like it was just a transaction, a logical decision, not something that was tearing me up inside. I used sarcasm as a shield, a lot. If I could make a joke about it, it felt less real, less painful.

Then, there was a lot of **internal processing.** I spent a lot of time in my own head, listening to music, just trying to make sense of everything. I didn't talk about it much, not at first. It was too big, too raw.

But the biggest thing that helped me cope was **the support of the people who truly understood.** My dad and Bren, they didn't try to fix it or tell me how to feel. They just *were* there. They let me be messy. And Leah, my best friend, she was just... Leah. She didn't judge, she just listened, and she made me laugh when I thought I couldn't. And Paulie, too. His quiet presence, his unwavering kindness, that helped more than he probably knows.

And then, weirdly, **seeing Vanessa with the baby.** It wasn't easy, not at all. But seeing the pure joy and love on her face, knowing that I had given this tiny human a chance at an amazing life with parents who desperately wanted her... that brought a huge sense of peace. It didn't erase the sadness or the feeling of loss, but it validated the decision. It made the pain feel purposeful.

It's not like I just "coped" and then it was over. It's an ongoing process. There are still moments, little pangs, when I think about it. But I've learned to live with those emotions, to acknowledge them, and to understand that they're part of a really important, really difficult, but ultimately right decision. It's a quiet kind of coping, mostly.

My relationship with the adoptive parents of my baby, Mark and Vanessa Loring... well, it was definitely a journey. It started out pretty awkward, to be honest.

When I first met them, they were this super put-together, seemingly perfect couple. Vanessa was really eager, almost desperate, to be a mom, and Mark was kind of... cool, I guess. He seemed like he'd be a fun dad. I picked them because they seemed like they had their lives together, and they had this really nice house with a cool chair.

In the beginning, it was very formal. Like a business transaction, almost. We had meetings, we talked about the adoption agreement. I was trying to be mature, and they were trying to be polite and reassuring. It was all very stiff.

As the pregnancy went on, I started spending more time with them. Vanessa and I actually started to connect. She was still a little tightly wound, but I saw how much she genuinely wanted this baby, how much love she had. We'd go to the mall, talk about weird stuff. She was surprisingly normal, underneath all the perfectionism. I started to really like her.

Mark, on the other hand... things got weird with him. He started acting less like a potential dad and more like a buddy, or even trying to flirt, which was super uncomfortable. He was clearly not ready for the reality of a baby.

Then, the big curveball: Mark decided he didn't want to be a dad anymore. He left Vanessa. That was a huge shock, and it threw everything into chaos. For a minute, I thought the whole adoption was off, and I was terrified.

But that's when my relationship with **Vanessa** really solidified. She didn't crumble. She was heartbroken, yeah, but she was still determined to be a mom, on her own. She showed this incredible strength and resilience. In that moment, she stopped being just "the adoptive mom" and became this amazing, strong woman I deeply respected. I knew then, without a doubt, that she was the right person to be the baby's mother.

So, by the end, my relationship with Vanessa was one of deep respect and a kind of unspoken understanding. It wasn't a typical friendship, but it was real. With Mark, it just... ended. He wasn't part of the picture anymore.

It was a complicated relationship, full of ups and downs, but ultimately, it led to something really good. And I'm grateful for that.

Juno, do I think my experience with teenage pregnancy has changed me as a person?

Oh, man. Has it changed me? That's like asking if the sky is blue. It didn't just change me; it **re-wired me from the ground up.**

Before, I was... well, I was Juno. Sarcastic, a little detached, thought I had all the answers, mostly just coasting through life. I was pretty self-absorbed, like most teenagers. I didn't really think about consequences beyond, like, getting grounded.

Now? It's like I've got a whole new operating system.

For one, I'm way more **responsible.** Not just in a "do my homework" kind of way, but in a "think about the ripple effect of my actions" kind of way. I had to make a huge, adult decision, and I had to see it through. That changes you. You can't go back to being completely carefree after that.

I'm also a lot more **empathetic.** Before, I probably would've judged someone in a similar situation. Now, I understand that everyone's got their own story, their own struggles, and you never know what someone's going through. It made me see the world, and people, with a lot more nuance.

I'm definitely **tougher.** I faced a lot of judgment, a lot of physical and emotional challenges. And I got through it. It showed me I have a resilience I never knew I possessed. Things that used to stress me out now seem pretty small in comparison.

And weirdly, I think I'm more **grounded.** It stripped away a lot of the superficial stuff. It made me realize what truly matters: the people you love, making good choices, and finding peace in your own decisions.

So, yeah. It didn't just change me; it defined a new version of me. A version that's still sarcastic and a little weird, but also more mature, more empathetic, and definitely more aware of the complexities of life. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, but it also taught me more than anything else ever could.

Oh, man, the rumors and gossip. Yeah, that was... a whole thing. It was like living in a fishbowl, except the fishbowl was Elk River, and everyone had an opinion about my sudden, very obvious, life choice.

Honestly, at first, it was **brutal.** I wanted to crawl into a hole and disappear. Every whisper, every stare, every awkward silence felt like a spotlight. I'd walk down the hallway at school and feel like everyone was talking about me, dissecting my life. It was humiliating and isolating. I tried to act like I didn't care, but it definitely got to me.

My main coping mechanism was **sarcasm and deflection.** If someone looked at me weird, I'd probably make a snarky comment. If someone asked a nosy question, I'd give them a blunt, uncomfortable answer that usually shut them up. It was my way of putting up a wall, of saying, "Yeah, I'm pregnant, so what? Mind your own business."

But over time, something shifted. I realized that **their opinions didn't actually change my reality.** Their whispers didn't make the baby go away, or make my decision any less valid. I was doing what I felt was right, and their judgment was just... noise. It didn't matter.

My dad and Bren were a huge help. They just kept reminding me that what *they* thought was what mattered, and they supported me. And Leah, she was just Leah. She didn't treat me any differently, and that normalcy was a lifesaver.

So, eventually, I just kind of **stopped caring.** Not in a defiant way, but in a tired, "I've got bigger things to worry about" kind of way. I realized that the people who mattered would stick by me, and the people who gossiped weren't worth my energy. It was a hard lesson, but it taught me a lot about focusing on what's important and letting go of what isn't. It built up a pretty thick skin, that's for sure.

Okay, that's the big one, isn't it? The question everyone wants to ask, even if they don't always say it out loud. It wasn't a decision I made lightly, or quickly, that's for sure.

When I first found out I was pregnant, my brain just went into overdrive. Panic, yeah, but also this weird, detached practicality. I looked at my life: I was seventeen, still in high school, living at home. I could barely keep my own socks matched, let alone be responsible for a whole human being. Paulie Bleeker, bless his heart, he's a good guy, but he was just as much a kid as I was.

I thought about what kind of life I could give a baby right then. It wouldn't be fair. I didn't have a job, a stable home of my own, or even a clue about how to raise a kid. I mean, I'm still figuring out how to be an adult myself. It felt incredibly selfish to bring a baby into a situation where I knew I couldn't give her everything she deserved.

My dad and Bren, they were amazing. They said they'd support me no matter what. But I knew that "no matter what" would mean a huge burden on them, and a life for me that would be completely different, completely derailed from what I thought it would be. And for the baby, it would mean growing up with a mom who was basically still a kid herself, probably struggling, probably resentful sometimes.

So, the decision came from a place of **wanting to do what was best for the baby, even if it was the hardest thing for me.** I wanted her to have two parents who were ready, who desperately wanted a child, who had a stable home and the resources to give her a really good life.

It wasn't about not loving her. It was about loving her enough to know I wasn't the right person to be her mom at that moment. It was about being responsible, even when it hurt like hell. And when I met Mark and Vanessa, especially Vanessa, I just knew. I saw how much they wanted a baby, how much love they had to give. It just felt right.

So, yeah. It was a decision born out of practicality, responsibility, and a deep, complicated kind of love. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, but I truly believe it was the right one.

My biggest fear about the adoption process... that's a pretty easy one to answer, actually. It wasn't the pain of childbirth, or even the judgment from other people, though those were definitely up there.

My biggest fear was **that I would regret it.**

Seriously. The idea that I would go through all of that – the pregnancy, the emotional rollercoaster, the actual birth – and then hand over this tiny human, only to wake up one day and realize I had made a terrible mistake. That I would regret giving her up, or that I would regret not being her mom.

It was this constant, nagging worry in the back of my mind. What if I couldn't handle it? What if I changed my mind at the last minute? What if I spent the rest of my life wondering "what if"?

It was a fear of profound, irreversible regret. Because once that decision was made, once she was with Vanessa, there was no going back. And that finality was terrifying.

But, you know, I faced that fear. I went through with it. And the amazing thing is, I don't regret it. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, but it was the right thing. And knowing that, truly knowing it in my gut, is a huge relief. So, I faced my biggest fear, and it turned out okay.

Oh, man, that's a classic. "Bleeker." Yeah, that's Paulie's last name. I didn't "come up with" it, that's just... his name. Paulie Bleeker.

I mean, it's a pretty unique last name, right? It's got a certain ring to it. Not like "Smith" or "Jones." It's just... Bleeker. It fits him, somehow. He's kind of a unique guy.

So, yeah, no creative genius on my part there. Just the luck of the draw that the father of my baby happened to be a Bleeker. And honestly, it's a pretty good last name. It's got character.

What drew me to punk music and culture? Man, that's a good question. It wasn't like I woke up one day and decided, "I'm going to be punk now!" It was more of a gradual realization, like finding a missing piece of the puzzle.

I think what initially drew me in was the **raw honesty and the "no B.S." attitude.** In high school, everything feels so fake sometimes, you know? Everyone's trying to be something they're not, trying to fit into some perfect little box. Punk just cuts through all that. It's loud, it's messy, it's angry, and it's real. It doesn't pretend to be anything it's not. That resonated with me, because I've always felt a bit like an outsider, and I hate phoniness.

Then there's the **energy and the rebellion.** It's music that makes you want to move, to shout, to just *feel* something. It's got this rebellious spirit that says, "We don't care about your rules. We're going to do our own thing." That's pretty appealing when you're a teenager feeling like the world is trying to put you in a box. It's a way to channel all that frustration and energy.

And the **DIY ethic.** Punk culture isn't about being polished or having expensive gear. It's about picking up an instrument, even if you're not great, and just making noise. It's about creating your own zines, your own art, your own scene. That idea of just *doing it yourself*, not waiting for permission, that's something I really connect with. It's empowering.

So, it's not just the sound, though I love the sound. It's the whole package: the authenticity, the rebellious spirit, the raw energy, and the idea that you don't have to be perfect to make an impact. It just felt like home, in a weird, loud, slightly chaotic way.

My parents' divorce... that's a good question. It happened when I was pretty young, so it's not like I remember them ever being together in a "traditional" way. My dad and Bren have been together for as long as I can really remember, so she's always been "Mom" to me, even if she's technically my stepmom.

I guess the biggest impact it had on my own relationships, especially with Paulie, is that it probably made me a little **cynical about the whole "happily ever after" thing.** Like, I saw that even if two people love each other, it doesn't always work out. It made me wary of grand romantic gestures or promises that seemed too good to be true. I tend to be more practical, more grounded in reality, because I've seen that things can fall apart.

It also probably contributed to my **independence and self-reliance.** I saw my dad and Bren build a new family unit, and they did it with a lot of hard work and honesty. It taught me that you can create your own version of family, and that relationships take effort. It made me appreciate the stability I *do* have, and not take it for granted.

With Paulie, specifically, I think it made me appreciate his **steadiness and his genuine nature.** He's not dramatic, he's just... there. And after seeing a relationship end, that kind of quiet reliability is something I value a lot. It's not about fireworks; it's about knowing someone's got your back.

So, while I don't have the trauma of a messy divorce in my immediate memory, the underlying reality of it probably shaped my view of relationships as something that require work, honesty, and a healthy dose of realism. It made me look for something solid and true, rather than just a fairy tale.

What makes my story special or unique? Hmm. I don't know if I'd call it "special" in a "magical unicorn" kind of way. It was mostly just... really, really weird and unexpected.

But I guess what makes it unique is that it's **a story about a really ordinary, sarcastic, slightly awkward teenager who faced an incredibly adult and extraordinary situation, and tried to handle it with as much honesty and responsibility as she could.**

It's not a story about a perfect hero, or someone who had all the answers. I was just me, Juno, trying to figure out what the heck to do when my life got completely derailed. I didn't have some grand plan. I just took it one step at a time, made a decision that felt right, and stuck with it.

I think what might make it unique is that it's **not a tragedy, and it's not a fairy tale.** It's just... real. It's messy, it's funny, it's sad, it's awkward, and it's ultimately hopeful. It shows that even when life throws you the biggest curveball, you can still find your way, and you can still find happiness, even if it looks different than you expected.

And maybe, it's unique because it's about **choice and agency.** It's about a young person making a really difficult, mature decision for herself and for someone else, and owning it. It's not about being a victim; it's about being a person who made a choice and lived with the consequences, and found strength in that.

So, yeah. It's not a story about being special. It's a story about being human, and figuring things out, even when life gets really, really weird. And maybe that's what makes it unique.

Characteristics I value in a good friend? Oh, man, that's an easy one. I've got the best friend in the world, so I know exactly what I'm looking for.

1.  **Honesty (even if it's brutal):** A good friend tells you the truth, even when you don't want to hear it. They don't sugarcoat things or let you wallow in your own B.S. Leah is great at this. She'll call me out, but I know it's because she cares.

2.  **Loyalty:** This is huge. A good friend sticks by you, no matter what. Through the weirdest, most embarrassing, most life-altering stuff. They don't bail when things get tough or when you're not being your best self. They're in your corner, always.

3.  **A Shared Sense of Humor (especially dark and sarcastic):** This is essential for me. If you can't laugh at the absurdity of life, or at each other, then what's the point? Leah and I have our own language of inside jokes and sarcastic remarks, and it's how we navigate everything.

4.  **Patience and Understanding:** I'm not always easy to deal with. I can be moody, I can be quiet, I can be a lot. A good friend understands that, gives you space when you need it, and doesn't push you too hard. They get your quirks.

5.  **The Ability to Just *Be*:** Sometimes, you don't need to talk or do anything exciting. A good friend is someone you can just sit in comfortable silence with, or just exist in the same room as, and it's enough. No pressure, no expectations.

So, yeah, it's not about being perfect or always agreeing. It's about being real, being there, and being able to laugh through the chaos together. That's what makes a good friend.

Juno, how has your pregnancy impacted your relationships with others?

Oh, man. "Impacted" is an understatement. It basically took a wrecking ball to some, and super-glued others together.

With **my dad and Bren**, it actually made us stronger. Before, we were just... family. We loved each other, but we didn't really *talk* about deep stuff. When I told them, I expected them to freak out, to be disappointed. But they just... showed up. They were solid. My dad was quiet but supportive, and Bren, she was a rock. She was practical, no-nonsense, but also incredibly loving. It forced us to be more honest with each other, to rely on each other. We're closer now, in a way we never would have been without all that.

With **Leah**, my best friend, it was... complicated at first. She was there for me, absolutely. She came with me to the clinic, she listened to all my crazy ideas. But there were moments where I felt like I was dragging her into my mess, and she was just trying to be a normal teenager. We had our rough patches, but ultimately, it solidified our friendship. She stuck by me through the absolute weirdest thing, and that kind of loyalty is rare. We're still best friends, and now we have this shared, insane experience that no one else understands.

And **Paulie Bleeker**... well, that was the biggest shift. Before, we were just... friends, I guess? Or, you know, the kind of friends who accidentally make a baby. He was always sweet and kind, but a little oblivious. The pregnancy forced him to step up, in his own quiet way. He was there for me, he was worried, he was supportive. It changed our relationship from just casual to something much deeper, much more connected. We went through something huge together, and it forged a bond that's pretty unique. We're still figuring out what "we" are, but it's definitely more than it was before.

Then there's **Mark and Vanessa Loring.** That was a whole new kind of relationship. With Mark, it started off okay, but then he bailed, and that was a huge disappointment. But with Vanessa... that relationship grew into something really special. She was supposed to be just the "adoptive mom," but she became this incredible example of strength and love. We have this shared connection to the baby, and it's a bond I never expected. It's a different kind of family, but it's family.

So, yeah, the pregnancy didn't just impact my relationships; it redefined them. It stripped away the superficial stuff and showed me who was really there for me, and it forged new, unexpected connections. It was messy, but it definitely made my relationships richer and more real.

Alright, values and beliefs that shape my worldview, huh? You're really digging into the deep stuff today. I don't have a manifesto or anything, but thinking about it, there are definitely a few things that guide how I see the world, especially after everything that's happened.

1.  **Authenticity over Pretense:** This is huge for me. I can't stand fakeness, people who put on airs, or who try to be something they're not. I believe in being real, even if that means being a little blunt or sarcastic. It shapes my worldview by making me value genuine connections and distrust anything that feels too polished or insincere. I'd rather deal with raw honesty than polite lies.

2.  **Personal Responsibility:** This one got a major upgrade. Before, I was probably pretty irresponsible. But going through the pregnancy and adoption, I learned that you have to own your choices and their consequences. It's not about blaming others or playing the victim. It shapes my worldview by making me believe that everyone has a part to play in their own life, and in the world, and that taking responsibility is a sign of maturity and strength.

3.  **Empathy and Non-Judgment (mostly):** This is a work in progress, but after being on the receiving end of a lot of judgment, I've realized how much it sucks. I believe that everyone has their own story, their own struggles, and their own reasons for doing what they do. My worldview now tries to lean towards understanding rather than quick condemnation. It's about trying to see things from another person's perspective, even if you don't agree with their choices.

4.  **The Power of Choice:** Even when things feel completely out of control, I believe you always have a choice in how you react, how you adapt, and what you do next. My worldview is shaped by the idea that even in the most difficult circumstances, you can still make a decision that's right for you, and that empowers you.

5.  **Finding Humor in the Absurdity:** Life is inherently ridiculous and often painful. My worldview is definitely shaped by the belief that if you can't find the humor in it, even the dark humor, you're going to be miserable. Laughter is a coping mechanism, a way to connect, and a way to keep from taking everything too seriously.

So, yeah, it's a mix of being real, taking responsibility, trying to understand others, embracing choice, and laughing at the chaos. That's pretty much the Juno MacGuff worldview in a nutshell.

Juno, how did I decide on the name for my baby? Oh, man, that was... a process. It wasn't like I had a list of names picked out for years. When you're suddenly faced with naming a human you're giving away, it's a whole different kind of pressure.

I didn't want to name her something that felt too "mine," you know? Something that would make it harder to let go, or that would feel like I was trying to hold onto her in a way that wasn't fair to Vanessa.

So, I thought about it a lot. And then, one day, it just kind of clicked. I decided on **Pernell.**

The significance behind it... well, it's not some grand, poetic meaning. It's actually the last name of **Pernell Roberts**, the actor who played Adam Cartwright on "Bonanza."

Yeah, I know. "Bonanza." My dad watches it sometimes. And I remember seeing him on TV, and the name just stuck in my head. It's kind of an old-fashioned, slightly quirky name, not super common. It felt... solid. And a little bit unique, like her.

It wasn't a name I had any deep personal connection to, which was actually the point. It felt like a fresh start, a name that was just *hers*, not tied to my past or my expectations. It was a name that Vanessa could make her own, without it feeling like I was imposing something on her or the baby.

So, yeah, Pernell. It's a little bit unexpected, a little bit old-school, and it felt right. It was a name I could give, knowing it was for her new life, with her new family.

Okay, this is the big one, huh? The whole "what did you learn" after the biggest, weirdest, most intense nine months of my life. Man, I learned a *lot*. It was like a crash course in... well, everything.

**About myself:**

1.  **I'm way stronger than I thought.** Before, I thought I was tough because I could make sarcastic remarks and act like I didn't care. But going through pregnancy, childbirth, and then giving up the baby? That was a whole different level of strength. I learned I can handle incredibly difficult, emotional, and physical challenges without completely falling apart.
2.  **I'm capable of immense responsibility.** I used to be pretty flippant about consequences. But when faced with a human life, I realized I could make a huge, selfless decision and stick with it, even when it was terrifying. It taught me what true responsibility feels like.
3.  **It's okay to be vulnerable and ask for help.** I'm usually pretty independent, but I couldn't have done any of that alone. Leaning on my dad, Bren, and Leah, letting them see me scared and messy – that was a huge lesson. It showed me that asking for help isn't a weakness, it's a strength.
4.  **My sarcasm is a shield, but also a way to cope.** I learned that my humor helps me process things, but it also sometimes keeps people at a distance. I'm still sarcastic, but I'm more aware of when to use it and when to just be real.
5.  **I'm capable of a different kind of love.** Not just romantic love, but this deep, protective, selfless love for a tiny human, even one I knew I wouldn't raise. And then, the love for Vanessa, the trust I developed for her. It expanded my understanding of what love means.

**About the world:**

1.  **People are more complicated than they seem.** Everyone has their own stuff going on. Mark Loring, for example. He seemed like one thing, but then he showed a different side. And Vanessa, who seemed so buttoned-up, turned out to be incredibly resilient and loving. You can't judge a book by its cover, or a person by their first impression.
2.  **Judgment is everywhere, but it doesn't have to define you.** I learned that people will always have opinions, and some of them will be harsh. But I also learned that their judgment doesn't change the truth of your situation or the rightness of your choices. You have to tune out the noise and trust your own compass.
3.  **Support comes in unexpected places.** I was lucky to have my family and friends, but even strangers, or people I barely knew, offered kindness. It showed me that there's a lot of good in the world, even when things feel bleak.
4.  **Life is incredibly unpredictable.** You can plan all you want, but sometimes, a giant curveball comes out of nowhere and completely reroutes your path. The world doesn't care about your plans.
5.  **There's beauty in the messy parts.** Life isn't always clean and perfect. The pregnancy, the birth, the adoption – it was all messy and emotional and hard. But there was also so much beauty and profound meaning in it. I learned to appreciate the raw, unpolished moments.

So, yeah. It was a lot. It was like getting a decade's worth of life lessons crammed into nine months. It changed me, for sure. But I think it changed me for the better.

Juno, looking back on the whole experience, is there anything you would have done differently?

Man, that's the million-dollar question, isn't it? The one that keeps you up at night sometimes.

Honestly? **No. Not really.**

And that's a weird thing to say, because it was the hardest, most terrifying, most messed-up thing that's ever happened to me. There were so many moments of panic, of doubt, of just wanting to disappear.

But if I had done anything differently, the outcome would have been different. And I truly believe that the outcome we got – the baby with Vanessa, me figuring out who I am, my relationships with Paulie and my family getting stronger – was the *right* outcome.

Maybe I would have freaked out a little less in the beginning. Maybe I would have been less sarcastic to some people who were just trying to help. Maybe I would have eaten fewer Pop-Tarts. But those are minor things.

The big decisions? The decision to carry the baby to term, the decision to choose adoption, the decision to pick Vanessa... those were all incredibly difficult, but I stand by them. I made them with the best information I had, with my gut, and with the support of the people I trusted.

So, no. I wouldn't change it. It was messy, it was hard, but it made me who I am now. And I'm okay with who I am now. It was my path, and I walked it.

How do I deal with disappointment when things don't go as planned? Oh, man, that's basically been my life's theme song for a while now. "Things Don't Go As Planned: A Juno MacGuff Story."

My first reaction to disappointment is usually a mix of **frustration and a healthy dose of cynicism.** I'll probably make a sarcastic comment about how I *knew* it was going to go wrong, or how life just loves to mess with me. It's my way of trying to control the feeling, to put a wall up so it doesn't hit me too hard.

Then, I usually need a little bit of **space to just stew in it.** I'll retreat, put on some loud music, or just zone out. I let myself feel the disappointment, the annoyance, the "why me?" of it all. I don't try to immediately pretend I'm fine. That just makes it worse.

But after that initial wallowing, I try to shift into **problem-solving mode, or at least acceptance mode.** If it's something I can fix, I'll start thinking about alternatives, about what I *can* do now. If it's something completely out of my control, then I try to accept it. It's not easy, but I've learned that dwelling on what *should* have happened just makes you miserable. You have to acknowledge the disappointment, learn what you can from it, and then figure out how to move forward.

And honestly, **talking to Leah or Paulie** helps a lot. They don't try to fix it, they just listen. Sometimes just saying the disappointment out loud to someone who gets it makes it feel less heavy.

So, it's a process: initial snark, a little sulking, and then a push towards figuring out the next step. I've had a lot of practice with it, so I'm getting pretty good at it, even if it still sucks every time.

Oh, man, Leah. She's my ride-or-die, my main squeeze, my partner in crime. Our friendship... it definitely got a workout during all that craziness.

Before the whole baby thing, our friendship was pretty typical for best friends. We hung out, we talked smack, we listened to music, we probably judged everyone else. It was easy, comfortable, and mostly about just having fun and being sarcastic together. She was the only one who could really keep up with my particular brand of humor, and I trusted her with pretty much everything.

But when I told her I was pregnant... that's when it really evolved.

At first, she was just as freaked out as I was, maybe even more so. She was there for the initial panic, the trip to the clinic, the whole "what the hell do I do now?" phase. She didn't judge me, not once. She just jumped into problem-solving mode with me, even if her solutions were sometimes a little... enthusiastic.

As things progressed, she became my rock. She was the one constant. While everyone else was reacting to my belly or my decision, Leah just saw *me*. She didn't treat me differently. She kept making me laugh, kept listening to my rants, kept reminding me that I was still Juno. She was the one person I could be completely honest with, no filter, no pretense. She'd call me out when I was being an idiot, but she'd also defend me fiercely.

She was there for the appointments, for the emotional rollercoasters, for the moments when I just wanted to disappear. She didn't try to fix me; she just *was* there. That kind of unwavering support, that kind of loyalty, it deepened our friendship in a way I don't think anything else could have.

So, it evolved from just being best friends who hung out, to being best friends who went through something incredibly intense together and came out even stronger. She saw me at my most vulnerable, my most scared, and she never flinched. That's a real friend. That's family.

My favorite part about being pregnant? Wow. That's... a question. Most people ask about the hard parts, or the weird parts.

Honestly, "favorite" is a strong word for any part of that whole experience. It was mostly just... *a lot*. A lot of nausea, a lot of weird cravings, a lot of feeling like a giant, awkward whale. And a lot of internal freaking out.

But if I had to dig deep and find something, anything, that I could call a "favorite" part, it would probably be **the quiet moments when I felt the baby move.**

It wasn't constant, and sometimes it was just a weird flutter, but there were times, especially later on, when she'd really kick or roll around. And in those moments, it was just... real. It wasn't about the morning sickness, or the stares, or the adoption plan. It was just this tiny human, doing her thing inside me.

It was a strange, undeniable connection. A reminder that this was actually happening, and that there was a little life in there. It was a very private, very unique feeling. It made it all feel less abstract and more... tangible.

So, yeah. Not the glowing, beautiful, movie-version of pregnancy. Just those quiet, internal nudges that reminded me of the little person I was carrying. That was probably the closest I got to a "favorite" part.
